summary: This document is a chain of emails from June 2020 between the FBI's New York CART (Computer Analysis and Response Team) and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) regarding the processing and transfer of digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein. The emails discuss delays, technical challenges, and coordination for reviewing terabytes of data from devices seized during Epstein's arrest and from search warrants executed at his residences in New York and the US Virgin Islands. This document is an email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) and FBI personnel regarding the organization and transfer of digital evidence from the Epstein investigation. It discusses confusion over which materials from search warrants executed at Epstein's New York mansion and Virgin Islands properties have been provided, the need for a tracking system, and the massive volume of data (over a million documents).

persons.name: IMP, IM I.
persons.context: FBI agent from New York who forwarded an email about expediting copies of Epstein's seized phone and tablet to the review team.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the investigation; digital evidence was seized from his person during his arrest and from his residences.

persons.name: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: Responds to the U.S. Attorney's Office, providing an accounting of digital evidence transferred from the New York and Virgin Islands searches, noting that all Windows items and loose media from NY have been handed over, and that some Apple items remain.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York
persons.context: Author of the initial email expressing frustration and confusion over tracking the massive volume of Epstein search warrant materials, requesting a meeting and a detailed spreadsheet to organize the evidence flow.

connections.description: FBI agent involved in the investigation and evidence handling related to Epstein's case.

connections.person1: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York
connections.person2: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
connections.description: Correspondence regarding the transfer and organization of digital evidence from the Epstein investigation, with the prosecutor requesting clarity and the FBI examiner providing status updates.

events.title: Coordination on Evidence Transfer
events.description: Email chain discusses expediting the transfer of copies of Epstein's seized phone and tablet to the review team and planning a meeting for the following Monday.

events.title: Search Warrants Executed
events.description: Search warrants were executed at Epstein's residences in New York and the US Virgin Islands, resulting in the seizure of numerous digital devices.

events.title: Search Warrants Executed
events.description: Search warrants were executed at Epstein's residences, as referenced in the context of pending data production.

events.title: Prior Property Search
events.description: A search of one of Epstein's properties in July 2007 yielded 9 IDE hard drives (3 sets of copies) that were among the evidence processed.

events.title: Initial Request for Evidence Tracking
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney sends an email expressing confusion over received Epstein search warrant materials and requests a systematic way to track what evidence has been provided.
personsInvolved: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York

events.title: FBI Examiner Provides Evidence Status Update
events.description: An FBI forensic examiner responds to the prosecutor's request, detailing which digital items from the New York and Virgin Islands searches have been transferred and which are still pending.
personsInvolved: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner

locations: Island (likely referring to Epstein's private island)
keyFacts: The FBI's New York CART team was processing terabytes of digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's arrest and from search warrants at his New York and US Virgin Islands residences.
Evidence included phones, tablets, loose media, cameras, DVRs, servers, laptops, desktop computers, and hard drives from a 2007 search.

Significant delays in evidence review were caused by staffing issues, the COVID-19 pandemic (teleworking), and technical challenges in formatting data for the Relativity e-discovery tool used by prosecutors.
Prosecutors expressed frustration over prior data transfers being in an unusable format, lacking links between emails and attachments, and having mismatched control numbers.
The correspondence highlights the massive scale and complexity of the digital forensic investigation into Epstein's activities.
The digital evidence from the Epstein investigation was massive and poorly organized, causing significant confusion for prosecutors, with over a million documents and no clear tracking system.

Search warrants were executed at two primary locations: Epstein's New York mansion (yielding ~40 storage devices and 60+ CDs) and his Virgin Islands properties (yielding >25 devices including servers).
The FBI conducted an initial screen of picture files from CDs for child pornography (CP) and found none, but prosecutors still needed copies for review.
A major data transfer issue occurred because the FBI's network was being replaced, mandating the deletion of about 400 TB of old data, complicating evidence handling.

The correspondence highlights the logistical challenges of managing a high-profile investigation with vast amounts of digital evidence, requiring coordinated meetings between the U.S. Attorney's Office and the FBI.
